fields.description:
Taken from : https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/make-it-harder-to-squash-merge-by-accident-by-prov/365898

Squash merge is a useful feature, *but in many repos, individual commits are critically valued as a way to preserve history of distinct changes.* In other cases, the history of a long running source branch is substantial, and real merges are required to avoid fomenting a pattern of chronic merge conflicts, or even merge errors. In such environments a squash merge at the end of a Pull Request can be damaging to the repo, requiring mitigations such as force-push and recreation of the merge to repair the history when it is done in error. There are three costly aspects of the squash merge today:

1 - It is very easy to squash merge when it is not desired because the squash merge setting is sticky in the VSTS UI. It might be appropriate for one PR and not the next, but the UI doesn't allow for that nuance. Using squash on one PR is not a relevant predictor for whether it is a good idea for the next one. - One factor that exacerbates this is that there is a scenario where it is very likely for squash merge to be safe, regardless of the usual policy, and that is where the PR includes only one commit to begin with. In such cases, a true merge will create a history with an uninteresting fork, and many of the justifications for avoiding squash merge don't apply. If you generally want to avoid squash merge, but enable it to simplify the graph where possible for single commits, then you have to enable and disable the feature from one PR to the next, bouncing back and forth. Because of stickiness, it is not a consistent experience to simply enable it (or disable it) as needed, you have to consider the current sticky state and the desired target state.

2 - The squash merge setting is the last choice made when completing the UI, it is not undoable, and it is not reviewable.

3 - Repo owners have no ability to shape the culture of a repo with policy around squash merge. I recommend: - make squash merge a reviewable setting on the PR such that reviewers can block squash merges on individual PRs - allow repo policy to allow the squash merge setting to be sticky (i.e. a repo can allow the setting to be sticky or not sticky, for every user individually) - make squash merge separately sticky between PRs with 1 commit and PRs with > 1 commit. - allow repo policy to disable all squash merges - allow exception for PRs with exactly 1 commit - allow repo policy to disable squash merges FROM a list of branches, or branch name patterns - allow exception for PRs with exactly 1 commit - allow repo policy to require squash merges TO a list of branches, or branch name patterns - allow repo policy to default PRs with exactly 1 commit to squash merge, where permitted - allow repo policy to default PRs with > 1 commit to squash merge, where permitted
fields.summary: Make it harder to squash merge by accident, by providing repo policy and preferences

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Few users have reported that they are getting "Something went wrong" error while viewing the repository dashboard
 The issue is not specific to a browser and version and has occurred with multiple browsers
  
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # View the Bitbucket repository dashboard

h3. Expected Results

The user should be able to view the repository dashboard without any issue
h3. Actual Results

The user is unable to view the repository dashboard and gets a "something went wrong" error.
h3. Workaround

We are not able to reproduce the issue at our end hence not sure about the workaround that will work in all cases.

This issue could be due to the browser configuration. If you face the issue and would like us to investigate the issue to find out the root cause and fix it permanently, please check the following and let us know the results and we will investigate it further.
 * Is the issue happening in an incognito window, other browsers as well? - This is to check if the issue is specific to your browser settings.
 * The issue could be due to the browser extensions/add-ons. Could you please try disabling all the extensions/add-ons on the browser and see if that helps?
 * Could you please try clearing the browser cache, cookies and see if that helps.
 * If none of the above helps, please generate a HAR file and share it with us for further investigation. Please refer to the documentation linked below for steps to generate the HAR file. [Generating HAR files and analyzing web requests|https://confluence.atlassian.com/kb/generating-har-files-and-analyzing-web-requests-720420612.html]
fields.summary: "Something went wrong error" while viewing the repository dashboard

Often I need to copy the code block but it's currently cumbersome.
fields.summary: Copy Button for code

fields.description:
Bitbucket pipelines give us the opportunity to create custom pipelines, in these we  create some variables that will receive values entered manually by the user.

 
{code:java}
pipelines: 
  custom: 
    create_value: 
      - variables:  
          - name: SECRET_VALUE 
      - step:   
          script:
            - echo ok{code}
 

This is cool. You can create a custom step that will be triggered by the user (via Run Pipeline button)and the value for the var SECRET_VALUE will be provided by the user.

But there's a catch, the value of the variable will be printed in the logs/results. This means we cannot use custom steps for sensitive info. The message printed in the build results/log looks like the following:
{code:java}
Pipeline Variables: 
   SECRET_VALUE: my_secret_word
{code}
Can we have a feature to be toggled on/off in the repository _Pipelines_ config where we can choose if custom variables will be printed or not in the logs/results?

Or maybe an option in the pipeline itself like this:
{code:java}
pipelines: 
  custom: 
    create_value: 
      - variables:  
          - option: dontlogvars
          - name: SECRET_VALUE 
      - step:   
          script:
            - echo ok{code}
Thx!

 

{{}}{{}}
fields.summary: Suppress custom variables to be printed in the logs

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Commit branch will show the branch it was merged into only and does not show the source of the branch it was merged before. For example, Branch development merges into Master, the UI should show Development and Master, but it only shows the Master branch alone, which is confusing. Changing the main branch in repo settings will also change the UI branch to follow the main branch.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create branch development from master
 # Create bug branch from development
 # Create a commit and PR to development from bug branch
 # Merge the PR
 # Ui will show the commit UI as Bug and development branch
 # Create PR from development to master and merge
 # Ui will now show master is the branch; it's not showing development branch that was the source branch
 !Screenshot 2021-06-24 at 9.54.40 AM.png|thumbnail! 
 # Changing the main branch in the repo setting also change the UI
 !Screen Shot 2021-06-23 at 17.22.02.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Expected Results
It should show the source of the branch and destination branch in the UI.

h3. Actual Results
The UI shows the main branch and no Source branch.


h3. Workaround
No Workaround is available at this moment.
fields.summary: Commit UI only show the destination of the Merge Pull request

fields.description:
Currently if we want to publish to all production environments, we need to mention each environment name using the deployment keyword in bitbucket-pipelines.yml as shown below. This is not efficient if there are many environments.
{code:java}
image: node:10.15.0
definitions: 
  steps:
    - step: &production-deploy
        name: Deploy to production
        deployment: prod
        script:
          - script 1
          - script 2
          - #some more script
....
....
....
....

  branches:
    production:
    - parallel: 
        - step: 
          <<: *production-deploy
          name: Deploy to prod_env_1
          deployment: prod_env_1
        - step: 
          <<: *production-deploy
          name: Deploy to prod_env_2
          deployment: prod_env_2
        - step: 
          <<: *production-deploy
          name: Deploy to prod_env_3
          deployment: prod_env_3
        - step: 
          <<: *production-deploy
          name: Deploy to prod_env_4
          deployment: prod_env_4 {code}
It would be great if there is an option to specify deployment to all the environments belonging to an environment type. (example: deploy to all production environments)
fields.summary: Option to specify deployment to all the environments belonging to an environment type

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Sometimes requesting the [diffstat|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/diffstat/%7Bspec%7D] endpoint can cause the operation to fail with a 555 or 504 status code due to performance issues.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

(i) This can only be reproduced under certain specific circumstances, not all requests will fail.
 # Request the [diffstat|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Bworkspace%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/diffstat/%7Bspec%7D] endpoint

h3. Expected Results

No errors and a 2xx status code are returned.
h3. Actual Results

A {{555 - Unable to respond in time}} or a \{{504 Gateway Time-out}} error is returned.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available. 
 In some cases, retrying the operation at a different time will work.
fields.summary: Sometimes requesting the diffstat endpoint can cause 555 or 504 status code

This feature request is to add the ability, on the MS Teams integration, to add all repositories on a given workspace in Bitbucket.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When users enable `Require 2SV` access control feature on Personal workspace, Pipelines unable to use JWT token to perform authentication to proceed with the build (unless the Personal account has 2SV enabled)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # On a Personal workspace, add the "Require 2SV" access control
 # Attempt to enable and use Pipelines

h3. Expected Results
Pipelines would not be affected by the "Require 2SV" access control.

h3. Actual Results
Pipelines no longer executes, unless 2SV is enabled.

h3. Workaround
Either set up 2SV for the Bitbucket Account, while having `Require 2SV` access control enabled, or disable the `Require 2SV` access control.
fields.summary: Having 'Require 2SV' enabled does not allow Pipelines to run on personal workspaces (BECO-688)

fields.description:
We are looking for a feature where issue key needs to get auto-populated in commit message when developer creates a branch from Jira. Currently, if we need to track commit messages in JIRA, then we need to enable "*Require issue keys in commit messages Users won't be able to push commits without issue keys*" feature in repository links, and developer needs to enter the issue key while committing the code.

 

We are looking for a feature when developers create a branch from Jira and issue key is present in branch name, then issue key automatically gets populated in commit message while developer is committing the code into repository without issue key and commit details automatically get tracked in JIRA.

 

Please let us know whether this feature available. If it's unavailable, then please take this request as a product enhancement.
fields.summary: Issue keys auto populated in commit messages on create branch from Jira

fields.description:
It'd be great if the pipelines of same thing queue itself instead of using the pipeline minutes.

In our environment, we have multiple developers working on the same project. Sometimes 2 devs merge their PRs to the staging branch and the pipeline kicks of to deploy the corresponding change. If dev1 change is huge, it takes a lot of time to deploy dev1's change and meanwhile, the dev2 pipeline runs waiting for dev1's change to be deployed. If there is a way to queue the pipelines for the same branch or the same manual pipeline and work in a FIFO manner that'd be a huge plus.
fields.summary: Ability to Queue the pipelines
Update Repository Access feature is not present anymore after the Workspace settings update

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Few customers are reporting that after making changes in the source branch, their Pull requests are not being updated immediately with the latest changes in the source. The customer has to wait for some time (appx 15-20 mins) for the Pull request to show the latest changes
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Make some changes in the source branch
 # View the Pull request having the same source branch updated in the above first step. Observe the changes in the source branch is not visible in the Pull request

h3. Expected Results

The pull request should show the recent changes in the source branch
h3. Actual Results

The pull doesn't show the recent changes in the source branch
h3. Workaround

There are a couple of workarounds that customers can use until the issue is fixed -
 # Use the branch view to see the diff
 ## Got to the [https://bitbucket.org/]<workspace name>/<repo_name>/branches/
 ## Select the branch
 # Wait for some time (appx 15-20 mins) for the pull request to show the latest changes in the source branch
 # Try opening the PR’s edit page and saving it when the issue is encountered. That should force the PR to be updated.
fields.summary: Source branch changes doesn't immediately visible in the Pull request

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Unable to import issues from one repository to another due to file size

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open: https://bitbucket.org/<workspaceID>/<repoSlug>/admin/issues/import-export
# Click on "start export" and download the file
# Go to the destination repository -> https://bitbucket.org/<workspaceID>/<repoSlug>/admin/issues/import-export
# Click on "Choose file" under "Import issues" and select the file



h3. Expected Results
Successful import

h3. Actual Results

# The import fails with the below error 

{code:java}
upstream connect error or disconnect/reset before headers. reset reason: connection termination
{code}

h3. Workaround

Import issues in the destination repository via API

{code:java}
curl <username>:<password> -X POST -F archive=@/path/to/zip https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/<workspace>/<repository/issues/import
{code}
fields.summary: Issues import fails if the zip file size is huge

fields.description:
When reviewing a pull request, it'd be useful to have the option to comment on a diff privately (only viewable by you, the commenter). This could be as a private line/file comment, or a form of bookmarking/tagging with intent to come back to it later in the review process.

Pull requests present the touched files alphabetically, but during peer review the reviewer often has to traverse through referenced files (import/export) to gain a holistic understanding. This usually involves scrolling up/down the PR page, or using the file tree (depending on the UI mode) to traverse between files.

As a reviewer, sometimes you notice something that doesn't look quite right, but you need to double check code elsewhere to confirm. In these cases you can either double check immediately, or write a note in a notepad to come back to that piece later, and continue reviewing.

An inlined digital note mechanism would be useful. It would allow you to jot down your thoughts at the time, without spamming others with your incomplete assessment.

I envision private notes would either be replaced with finalised comments (once validated), or deleted (in the event your initial thought/interpretation was wrong).
fields.summary: Private PR comments or notes

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Adding a Slack message link on a pull request comment can not be saved. 

*Issue #1*
If a link to a Slack message is added to the pull request comment alone (No other text) The message is hidden when saved

*Issue #2*
If a link to a Slack message is added to the pull request comment with additional text the comment is in a sending state and the comment is removed when navigating away from the page 

h3. Steps to Reproduce (Issue #1)
# Integrate with Bitbucket Repository with Slack
# Copy a Slack message link 
# Paste the Slack message link in with no additional text 
# Click Save
# Comment is hidden and does not save

 !Slack_issue1.gif! 

h3. Steps to Reproduce (Issue #2)
# Integrate with Bitbucket Repository with Slack
# Copy a Slack message link 
# Paste the Slack message link in with no additional text add some text
# Click Save
# Comment is sending and never saves

 !Slack_issue2.gif! 

h3. Expected Results
Comment should save with a preview of the Slack message

h3. Actual Results
* Issue #1 - Message is hidden and does not save
* Issue #2 - Comment is sending and never saves

h3. Workaround
* Embed the link into the text

!Screen Shot 2021-06-23 at 17.55.51.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Adding Slack link on a pull request comment cannot be saved

fields.description:

It would be a good idea to be able to filter through commit messages with Regex to determine if commits with a certain string should trigger the notification, for example.
fields.summary: Add ability to better filter slack notifications

fields.description:
When manually running a pipeline from Pipelines > Run Pipeline it only allows you to select a branch from the dropdown. We tag all of our releases, so if we need to deploy a previous release for rolling back it requires creating a new branch based on a tag. It would be nice if you could select a tag directly from the dropdown list as well.

 

!image-2021-06-18-10-36-35-440.png!
fields.summary: Pipelines: Support selecting tags when manually running a pipeline

fields.description:
I frequently use Bitbucket Cloud search to look for keywords within our Organisation's hundreds of Bitbucket Cloud repos. I don't know exactly which repositories I need to look in and the results might include hits in many files from many repos, listed in repo order. I usually want to scan through the list of repos that contain the keywords to identify the one or two to drill down into, as most repositories I can immediately identify by name as being not relevant. 

Because the results are listed in repo order, and a repo might have many many files with keyword hits, I can't easily see the list of implicated repositories without stepping through tens of search result pages.
It would be much more efficient to be able to view the list of distinct repositories implicated in a search, each of which is a link to repeating the search with repo:<name> added to the filter

e.g. current search results behaviour:
{code:java}
1979 code results in account: 1Spatial:
Old_irrelevant_Repo1\folder\source_code_file1.fortran
<details>
Old_irrelevant_Repo1\folder\source_code_file2.fortran
<details>
Old_irrelevant_Repo1\folder\source_code_file3.fortran
<details>
Old_irrelevant_Repo1\folder\source_code_file4.fortran
<details>
Old_irrelevant_Repo2\folder\source_code_file1.fortran
<details>
Old_irrelevant_Repo2\folder\source_code_file2.fortran
<details>

<1 2 3 4 5 ... 100>
{code}
 
Output of "distinct repositories" list each of which when clicked on adds the repository filter
{code:java}
1979 code results in 6 distinct repositories in account: 1Spatial:
Old_irrelevant_Repo1 (400 matches in 4 files)
Old_irrelevant_Repo2 (300 matches in 22 files)
Old_irrelevant_Repo3 (1 match in 1 file)
Possibly useful repo 3 (2 matches in 2 files)
Possibly useful repo 1 (50 matches in 10 files)
Possibly useful repo 1 (2 matches in 1 file)
{code}
fields.summary: Show the distinct list of the source repositories of the files found in search results

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
If a user is logged out of Bitbucket and then try to access a the repo using the following link "https://bitbucket.org/<workspace>/<repo_name>/pull-requests/, the page loads forever.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Log out of Bitbucket
 # Try to access pull request page of your repo "https://bitbucket.org/<workspace>/<repo>/pull-requests/"
# The UI loads forever instead of redirecting to sign-in page
# Try to access the src page of a repo "https://bitbucket.org/<workspace>/<repo>/src/" 
# Users will be redirected to sign-in page

h3. Expected Results
User should be redirected to sign-in page

h3. Actual Results
Console error- 403

{code}
Access to fetch at 'https://id.atlassian.com/login? ******* from origin 'https://bitbucket.org' has been blocked by CORS policy: Response to preflight request doesn't pass access control check: No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource. If an opaque response serves your needs, set the request's mode to 'no-cors' to fetch the resource with CORS disabled.
{code}

h3. Workaround
 Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Redirection to sign-in error

fields.description:
I have a situation where I need to be able to do a step if a filepath did not change AND separate filepath did change. I see this as something like:

 
{code:java}
step:
  name: Test
  condition:
    changesets:
      includePaths:
        # path that must have changed
        resources/docs/**
      skipStepIfChangedPaths:
        # not the best name
        # skips step if any of the paths are changed
        global/**{code}
fields.summary: Bitbucket pipelines -  step:condition - allow step skip if paths not changed

fields.description:
All current [documentation showcases using GCP Service Account JSON Keys|https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/deploy-to-google-cloud/] for deploying with Bitbucket Pipelines Deployment. But these are notoriously insecure and hard to maintain and keep rotated.

GCP has several different solutions [detailed here|https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/identity-security/how-to-authenticate-service-accounts-to-help-keep-applications-secure]. I think the right solution is for Bitbucket to support Workload Identity Federation. Bitbucket supplies the ID Token, and we authenticate our Service Account(s) with it. Then there are no keys to manage/secure/rotate.
fields.summary: Support Workload Identity Federation for GCP Service Accounts

fields.description:
When using the repository importer, if the source has LFS files in it, the importer will not perform the LFS tracking to point to Bitbucket Cloud LFS, rendering the LFS files unusable in Bitbucket.

The repository importer documentation does not state that this is not possible (https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/import-a-repository/).

This feature request is to add the ability for the importer to automatically fetch LFS files from the source remote, and import these files as well.
fields.summary: Repository importer to track LFS files from external sources

fields.description:

We do have a character limit of 62 in the repo slug but none on the repository name. However, if the length of the repository name exceeds that limit, Bitbucket truncates the repository name to fit the repo slug under the character limit.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # It always happens with Repo slug name having more than 62 characters 

h3. Expected Results

The repository name should be same as supplied by the user
h3. Actual Results

Repository name gets truncated
h3. Workaround

Choose a shorter name for the repository
fields.summary: Repository URL doesn't get the completely name when it's longer than 62 characters

fields.description:
Customer use case:
{quote}The history of git commits has the PR number automatically added to its comments when user merge their PR

The history of the two previous repositories has commented with their respective PR numbers for example 700++ 

However, when the repositories are merged together by creating new repositories the Pull request ID (numbers) is reset to 1
{quote}

It's best if we have the feature to change this pull request ID according to user need.
fields.summary: Ability to change the Pull request ID (numbers)

fields.description:
Many organization’s have requirements where an individual who commits code should not have the ability to also deploy code. This is where [deployment permissions|https://bitbucket.org/blog/deployment-permissions-now-available-in-bitbucket-pipelines] can prevent this. 

However, this feature is only available on the premium plan. This is a security concern for non-premium plan users and should be an essential feature for Bitbucket Pipelines to increase security.
fields.summary: Deployment permissions should be available on all plans

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Currently, the Repository list in a workspace doesn't show if the repository is over the size limit for the oversize repositories and doesn't show any warning. The repository list currently only displays the Repository name, description, last updated date, and the build status.

Having the warning message in the repository list for the oversized repositories can be helpful for the users maintaining the workspace having a large number of repositories. Otherwise, the user will come to know about it only when the user opens the individual repository or push the changes and the warning message appears indicating the repository is oversize.

Also, it will be nice to send the periodic email about the oversize repository list to the Admins so they can take the appropriate action and reduce the repository size.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # View the repository list within a workspace

h3. Expected Results

The repository list displays the Repository oversize warning if applicable, Repository name, description, last updated date, and the build status.
 Also, send the periodic email about the oversize repository list to the Admins so they can take the appropriate action and reduce the repository size.
h3. Actual Results

The repository list doesn't display the Repository oversize warning if applicable if the repository size is over the limit
h3. Workaround

Currently, the user can open the individual repository and the UI will display an oversize limit if the repository is oversize. This warning may appear even when the user pushes the changes from local machine.
fields.summary: Repository list display the large repository warning message

fields.description:
Public repos on BB cloud are an attractive target for spammers, and the tools available to repo admins for dealing with spamming and defacement attacks on our public issue trackers and pull request comments are woefully inadequate.

*Repo administrators need more tools to immediately and permanently deal with an spam/defacement attacker in a timely manner*. When an attack recently happened, I marked the first few defacements as spam, but that did NOT prevent the attacker from continuing their abusive behavior. I finally had to disable our entire issue tracker in order to stop the malicious activity, denying all our users access to this resource for over 24 hours while awaiting response to an Atlassian support ticket (which eventually led to a global ban of the spammer's account for TOS violation).

As a repo administrator **I want a button or configuration option to instantly BAN a given user from creating any issues or comments anywhere on MY repo**. This would give me a simple mechanism to deal with an attacker in a timely manner, without needing to wait for the latency of an Atlassian support ticket to end an attack. Optionally this would also create an abuse report to Atlassian, so that spammers who are flagged as banned by multiple repos would be evaluated by support personnel for TOS violation to justify a global ban.

Lacking such a feature, all BB cloud public repos are very vulnerable to defacement by malicious actors.
fields.summary: Add a "ban this user" button for repo admins

Currently, the only way to receive notifications of watched objects is [via email|https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/manage-email-notifications-for-watched-objects/]. I find this method cumbersome and it clutters my inbox. I wish there would be a single place where I could get an overview of all notifications.

Therefore, I propose Bitbucket implements a "notification list" similar to Jira:
- A bell icon in the top right corner
- A little red dot in the icon when there are new notifications
- When you click on the icon, a list of recent notifications on watched objects

The list could be implemented as a popup, like Jira, or it could be a separate page for notifications. See {{github.com/notifications}} for an example of such a page.

For each notification, the list should show some basic information like the type of notification, the date/time, a preview of the content (the first words of a comment, the title of the pull request, etc.), basically the same information that's currently in the email you receive for each notification. Clicking on a notification should bring you to the same URL as clicking the link in the email. Finally, it should be possible to disable email notifications while still receiving notifications via the website.

Thanks for allowing me to suggest this new feature!
fields.summary: Overview of notifications for watched objects

h3. Issue Summary
On Bitbucket's UI, it's possible to create and commit a file named "\".
This file causes problems on the repository, as after creation, it's not possible to delete, open or edit this file.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
1. Navigate to any Bitbucket repo > Source > create a file named "\"
2. You will not be able to open or edit this file

h3. Expected Results
Users should be able to edit, alter or delete files named "\", or they shouldn't be able to create such files at all.

h3. Actual Results
There is nothing stopping users from creating a file named "\".

The UI should either stop users from creating files with the "\" character as their name, or it should allow users to open, edit or remove these files.

h3. Workaround
It's possible to alter or delete the file through Git directly by following the steps below through Git, which escapes the "\" character with itself:
{code}
rm \\
git add --all && git commit -m "removing \"
git push
{code}
fields.summary: Files named "\"

I need to buy

fields.description:
BCLOUD-16728 implemented the ability to disable artifact downloads for a step.

I have multiple artifacts generated from previous steps and then a step that only requires access to a small subset of those artifacts. I would like to be able to have fine grained control over the artifacts that are downloaded.

 

I would suggest it uses the same globbing as used to save artifacts.

 

For example, this example pipeline has 3 stages, where a step requires artifacts from the step before, but not any further back. It contains suggested new keys under the {{step:artifacts:download_filter}} key:
{code:java}
'example-pipeline':
  - step:
      name: Step A
      script:
       - do_stuff.a
      artifacts:
        paths:
          - artifacts_a/**
    - step:
      name: Step B
      script:
       - do_stuff.b
      artifacts:
        download_filter:
          - artifacts_a/**
        paths:
          - artifacts_b/**
    - step:
      name: Step C
      script:
       - do_stuff.c
      artifacts:
        download_filter:
          - artifacts_b/**
        paths:
          - artifacts_c/**
 {code}

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If user trigger a deployment in pipeline that contain more than 100 commits(say 200 commits), those Jira issues that only have its key show in 100-200 commits would not get pick up, and the status in the corresponding Jira issue won't be updated.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create deployment environments in repository settings -> pipelines -> deployment
 # Define a step that mark as deployment, like this:
{code:java}
pipelines:
  branches:
    ddev:
      step:
          name: Build and Test
          deployment: test
          script:
            - echo test{code}

 # Create a feature branch that have 101 commits, and first commit point to a Jira issue, while the rest of the commits don't point to that issue.
 # Merge the feature branch to ddev, and it will trigger the deployment step.

h3. Expected Results

You should see a new item call "test" in the *Releases* attribute on the Jira issue sidebar

!Screen Shot 2021-05-19 at 3.08.06 pm.png!
h3. Actual Results

Nothing shows up in Releases attribute on the Jira Issue sidebar
h3. Workaround

Unfortunately, we don't have a permanent workaround for it except that reduces the commits in the deployment. To do that, you can either break down the deployment into smaller pieces or you can utilise the `squash` function during PR merge, so it won't include that many commits in the deployment.
fields.summary: Pipeline deployments with more than 100 commits would not update status in corresponding JIRA tickets
